title: React's Component Model — A Paradigm Shift
summary: When Facebook open-sourced React in 2013, its component model and Virtual DOM diffing challenged the prevailing MVC paradigm and ultimately reshaped how the web is built.
background: Facebook faced a bug in its chat feature: the unread message count would update inconsistently. Traditional MVC bidirectional data flow made the bug difficult to reproduce.
response: The React team designed a unidirectional data flow model: data flows down through props, events flow up through callbacks. The Virtual DOM made frequent re-renders efficient.
outcome: React became the most widely used front-end library. Its component model influenced Angular, Vue, Svelte, and virtually every modern front-end framework.
lessons: Composition over inheritance produces flexible UIs
Performance abstractions (Virtual DOM) can simplify developer mental models
Open-sourcing core infrastructure builds ecosystem loyalty
discussion_questions: Why did React's component model resonate so strongly with developers?
How has React Hooks changed the component model?
